title: Rhetorical Devices Quiz
description: Master the art of persuasion by identifying powerful rhetorical techniques used in speeches and writing

questions.question: What rhetorical device involves asking a question that does not require an answer?
What is 'anaphora'?
options: The repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning of successive clauses
A mild way of expressing something unpleasant

questions.question: Martin Luther King Jr.'s 'I have a dream...' repeated at the start of successive sentences is an example of:
What is 'antithesis' in rhetoric?
options: The juxtaposition of contrasting ideas in balanced phrases

questions.question: 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times' is an example of:
What is 'chiasmus'?
options: A reversal of the order of words in parallel phrases
A figure of speech using exaggeration

questions.question: 'Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country' is an example of:
In Aristotle's model of persuasion, what does 'ethos' refer to?
options: An appeal to the speaker's credibility or character

questions.question: What does 'pathos' mean in rhetoric?
options: An appeal to the audience's sense of humor
An appeal to logic and reason

questions.question: What does 'logos' refer to in persuasive rhetoric?
options: An appeal to logic and reason

questions.question: What is 'metonymy'?
options: Substituting the name of something with something closely associated with it
A question that does not need an answer

questions.question: Using 'the Crown' to refer to the British monarchy is an example of:
What rhetorical device involves a deliberate understatement for emphasis or effect?
Saying 'not bad' to mean 'good' is an example of:
What is 'synecdoche'?
options: The repetition of a word for emphasis
A figure of speech where a part represents the whole or vice versa
